entry.title: Blogging in jupyter notebooks
entry.content:
This is a guide for people who want to self-host their blog. If you have no problem putting your content behind someone else’s paywall you can try embed jupyter notebook in medium

A couple of weeks ago I had this idea of setting up my personal website to render programming notebooks.

If you are not familiar with the term, basically a programming notebook is a type of document where you can experiment with code and see the result next to it visuallized as graphs or tables. This is how scientists and data analysts use the power of programming to tell stories. https://observablehq.com/explore is an example

Anyhow, the tasks were: dockerizing the render script, setting up continuous delivery and lastly come up with a way to make it play with my nextjs/webpack/mdx pipeline which has not been done by anyone before…

After playing with knitr then a bunch of similar tools for jupyter, I realised it’s just not worth doing it myself. My original motivation is to write more and explore data more, not goofing around with these tools.

So I looked up “blogging in jupyter notebooks”1. Luckily, this is not a novel concept. 2 projects showed up that do exactly it: Jupyter Book and fastpages

It doesn’t seem that one of them is clearly better than the other. Jupyter Book has a neat layout that is also suitable for book publishing (it’s actually intended for that) and a git-friendly format. On the other hand, fastpages’s layout seems minimalistic enough for blogging and it comes with github actions that are super easy to set up, so I went with it.

Fastai/fastpages setup

One thing that I love about fastpages is how easy it is to get started. It takes you about 5 steps in 10 minutes to get a website deployed on github pages with continuous delivery. The fact that you don’t need separate services for hosting, CMS, CI/CD or even a domain makes this a perfect fit for aspiring learners of data science/dataviz, who arent always from an IT background, to start blogging. All they need is a github account.

The process start with a one click setup, essentially forking the project into your github account, a bot then opens a pull request (PR) for you to configure with easy instructions. I said this is easy but obviously not like setting up a site on wordpress or wix. After all this is for those who are at least interested in programming so you need to familiarize yourself the concept of github repo, opening and merging a PR, then later pushing code to publish blog posts.

Once setup is done your site looks like this

At this point you can start writing, fastpages support 3 formats: md, ipynb and docx. Perhaps the coolest feature is its out of the box support of instantly spinning up an execution environment for any jupyter script on binder and Google Colab:

Supporting docx is also an interesting choice and I believe this is to make it more friendly to people who aren’t geeks. If you have a CV in docx format and are using fastpages to showcase your works you can just chuck it in along side with the rest of your writting. Even as a web developer I have no shame in saying that I sometimes layout better in MS Word’s borderless tables than in css.

There are a lot more to fastpages which you can have a look at the README to find out. Out of the box you can embed code, youtube videos & tweets. They are all powered by Jekyll plugins so if you are familiar with that ecosystem you can start tweaking the theme and add plugins at this point. For comments you can either use disqus (needs set up) or just host all the comments in your github repo to make your site self-contained.

Have fun blogging!

  1. There is also bookdown if you are interest in using Rmd instead ↩
